questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office with a 1-day history of fever and irritability. His mother reports that he has been pulling at his right ear frequently. The patient recently started attending a new day care center. The mother denies any respiratory symptoms, rash, or gastrointestinal symptoms. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination reveals a red, bulging tympanic membrane on the right side with limited mobility and a Chapman reflex point superior to the right clavicle. In addition to oral analgesic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sphenopalatine ganglion release, which enhances parasympathetic activity, can be used to treat thick nasal secretions (e.g., due to an upper respiratory tract infection), which this patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube placement may be considered to treat chronic otitis media or recurrent acute otitis media (≥ 3 episodes in 6 months or ≥ 4 episodes in 12 months), neither of which is seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with otitis media, inward rotation of the temporal bone may cause eustachian tube dysfunction. The Galbreath technique (mandibular drainage) involves slow rhythmic manipulation of the mandible anteriorly and medially (away from the affected ear). This technique can facilitate the opening of the eustachian tube, thereby restoring lymphatic drainage and reducing middle ear effusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Suboccipital release is aimed at relieving tension in the suboccipital muscles and improving vagus nerve function, thereby enhancing parasympathetic activity. This technique can be used to treat symptoms associated with vagus nerve dysfunction (e.g., headaches and nausea), which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is the first-line antibiotic agent for treating antibiotic-naive individuals with acute otitis media. However, oral administration is preferred because topical antibiotics are generally ineffective. Additionally, antibiotic therapy is only indicated in certain patient groups (e.g., children ≤ 6 months, no improvement of symptoms after 48–72 hours, or severe infection).
questions.hint: This child presents with fever, ear pulling, a red, bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy, and an anterior Chapman reflex point that corresponds to the middle ear, making acute otitis media the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of fever, fatigue, and a dry cough. She mentions that her symptoms have been gradually worsening, and she has difficulty breathing when lying flat on her back. She reports no recent travel or exposure to illness. Medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally, fine inspiratory crackles at lung bases, and an increased respiratory rate. A chest radiograph shows bilateral diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following techniques is most appropriate for decreasing sympathetic activity to improve recovery in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although thoracic lymphatic pump is used to treat respiratory conditions (e.g., pneumonia), this technique does not affect sympathetic activity.

B) CORRECT:

Sympathetic hyperactivity in the sinus membranes and bronchial tree leads to an increase in goblet cells, resulting in the production of dense, sticky lung secretions. Raising of ribs T2–T7 facilitates the thinning of mucus secretions by decreasing sympathetic activity. The patient is seated or placed in a supine position, and gentle pressure is applied to the thoracic sympathetic ganglia, which are ventrolateral to the spinal cord and run parallel to the thoracic spine. This technique transiently heightens sympathetic response leading to sympathetic inhibition, which decreases lymphatic vessel constriction and improves lymphatic return. Moreover, rib raising reestablishes the range of motion of the chest cage and restores maximum inhalation, which creates more negative intrathoracic pressure.

Rib raising is indicated to treat sympathetic hyperactivity in several conditions including lower respiratory infections (e.g., pneumonia) and congestive heart failure. Contraindications include recent fractures and bone malignancies.

C) INCORRECT:

Sphenopalatine ganglion treatment is indicated in patients with upper respiratory tract infections (e.g., to treat thick nasal secretions due to rhinitis). This technique enhances parasympathetic activity but does not affect sympathetic activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Thoracic inlet release is primarily indicated to treat lymphatic congestion (e.g., in thoracic outlet syndrome) and does not affect sympathetic activity.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracoabdominal diaphragm release improves respiration and thoracoabdominal diaphragm excursion (e.g., in respiratory infections) by manually resetting and guiding diaphragmatic range of motion. This technique does not affect sympathetic activity.
questions.hint: Diminished breath sounds bilaterally, fine inspiratory crackles at the lung bases, and increased respiratory rate combined with a chest radiograph showing bilateral diffuse interstitial infiltrates suggests viral pneumonia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is recovering in the hospital 3 days after a laparotomic cholecystectomy. She reports abdominal discomfort and bloating. Her appetite is reduced, and she has not had a bowel movement since the surgery. Her medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and osteoarthritis, for which she takes atorvastatin and ibuprofen. Physical examination reveals a soft but distended abdomen with diminished bowel sounds. The surgical incision is clean and dry. An x-ray of the abdomen shows dilated bowel loops and uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels. Intravenous fluid administration is begun and a nasogastric tube is placed. Which of the following osteopathic manipulative treatments is most appropriate to normalize sympathetic hypertonicity related to this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pump enhances lymphatic and venous return from the abdomen, especially at the thoracic duct, and can be beneficial in treating gastrointestinal dysfunctions, such as paralytic ileus. This technique, however, does not reduce the sympathetic hyperactivity in postoperative ileus and is contraindicated in a patient with a recent surgical incision on the abdomen.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac ganglion release reduces sympathetic tone from T5–T9 and is used to manage upper gastrointestinal tract dysfunctions rather than ileus. The celiac ganglion provides sympathetic innervation to the upper gastrointestinal tract (i.e., the stomach, liver, gallbladder, spleen, and portions of the pancreas and duodenum) via the greater splanchnic nerve (T5–T9).

C) CORRECT:

Paraspinal inhibition can be used as an adjunct treatment of postoperative paralytic ileus, which is characterized by increased sympathetic activation that results in decreased peristalsis. This technique is performed by applying gentle pressure along the paraspinal muscles at L1–L2, which targets the sympathetic innervation of the lower gastrointestinal tract, thereby decreasing sympathetic activity and promoting bowel motility.

Contraindications for paraspinal inhibition include rib or spinal fractures and recent spinal surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

Redoming of the diaphragm restores normal diaphragmatic excursion and can aid in respiration and lymphatic return. This technique does not reduce the sympathetic hyperactivity in postoperative ileus and is contraindicated in a patient with a recent surgical incision near the diaphragm.

E) INCORRECT:

Sacral rocking releases myofascial restrictions to the lumbosacral area and can normalize hyperparasympathetic activity in the pelvic organs. This technique is primarily indicated in conditions such as dysmenorrhea, pelvic congestion syndrome, and sacroiliac dysfunctions, not ileus.

F) INCORRECT:

Pelvic diaphragm release relieves tension in the pelvic floor and restores lymphatic flow, which can indirectly influence lower abdominal organs. Although pelvic diaphragm release might benefit this patient, this technique does not reduce the sympathetic hyperactivity in postoperative ileus.
questions.hint: Postoperative bloating, diminished bowel sounds, and dilated bowel loops combined with a uniform gas pattern indicate postoperative paralytic ileus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office with swelling and discomfort in his right arm. The swelling has gradually increased over the past 6 months, and he notices that it worsens when he leaves his arm hanging by his side for long periods. He has a past medical history of infective endocarditis that resolved with antibiotic therapy. He does not take any medications. He denies any tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use, but has an extensive history of intravenous heroin use. He has been sober for 3 years. His vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals significant nonpitting edema of the right hand and arm, thickened skin over the arm, and track marks in the antecubital fossa. Treatment for this patient should be initiated using which of the following osteopathic lymphatic techniques?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pectoral traction could help this patient's lymphatic drainage by treating affected tissues directly and encouraging lymphatic return at the axilla, but it is not the initial step in the lymphatic treatment sequence.

B) INCORRECT:

Thoracic lymphatic pump can help this patient's lymphatic drainage by improving intrathoracic pressure gradients, but it is not the initial step in the lymphatic treatment sequence.

C) CORRECT:

Lymphatic treatment follows a sequential order in which techniques that remove fascial restriction are followed by techniques that improve lymphatic flow. First, thoracic inlet myofascial release (or release of the other three major myofascial junctions, depending on the affected tissue) is performed to remove restriction from the right lymphatic duct. Then, thoracoabdominal diaphragm redoming, lymphatic pump, and mobilization of targeted tissues (e.g., pectoral traction or posterior axillary fold technique) are performed. Treatment should start at the site of terminal lymphatic drainage of the affected tissue, and then move peripherally to sites proximal to the affected tissue.

D) INCORRECT:

Upper extremity lymphatic pump could help this patient's lymphatic drainage by mobilizing lymphatic flow through open channels, but it is not the initial step in the lymphatic treatment sequence.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracoabdominal diaphragm redoming can help this patient's lymphatic drainage by augmenting respiration and optimizing lymphatic return, but it is not the initial step in the lymphatic treatment sequence.
questions.hint: This patient has signs of collapsed or sclerosed upper extremity veins due to intravenous drug use, which led to edema of his right arm. Terminal lymphatic drainage of the right upper extremity is at the right lymphatic duct. Ensuring freedom of the fascia surrounding the right lymphatic duct should be the first step when treating this patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the office with a 6-month history of recurrent abdominal pain, discomfort, bloating, and altered bowel habits. She reports alternating diarrhea and constipation accompanied by abdominal pain 2–3 times per week, often exacerbated by stress and relieved by bowel movements. She has made no changes to her diet and has not had fever, weight loss, or blood in her stools. Her past medical history is unremarkable. She does not take any medications. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use any other substances. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 70/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness to deep palpation of the abdomen above the umbilicus. There is a notable increase in peristalsis and hyperactive bowel sounds on abdominal auscultation. All other physical examination findings are normal. Which osteopathic manipulative treatment would most likely improve this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Treatment of a Chapman point at the tip of rib 12

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sacral rocking releases myofascial restrictions to the lumbosacral area and can normalize hyperparasympathetic activity in the pelvic organs. This technique is primarily indicated in conditions such as dysmenorrhea, pelvic congestion syndrome, and sacroiliac dysfunctions, not IBS.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac ganglion release reduces sympathetic tone from T5–T9 and is used to manage upper gastrointestinal tract dysfunctions, not IBS. The celiac ganglion provides sympathetic innervation to the upper gastrointestinal tract (i.e., the stomach, liver, gallbladder, spleen, and portions of the pancreas and duodenum) via the greater splanchnic nerve (T5–T9).

C) INCORRECT:

Paraspinal inhibition is used to decrease sympathetic tone and is indicated in patients with ileus. This patient has alternating diarrhea and constipation, not signs of bowel obstruction. Additionally, this technique is only applied at spinal cord levels L1–L2, not L3–L4, as these segments do not have sympathetic outputs to the gastrointestinal tract.

D) INCORRECT:

A Chapman point at the costal end of rib 12 corresponds to a viscerosomatic dysfunction of the appendix, e.g., appendicitis. While this patient does have lower abdominal pain, her pain is chronic and she does not have any classic symptoms of appendicitis (e.g., nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, lower right quadrant pain).

E) CORRECT:

Superior mesenteric ganglion release normalizes sympathetic tone at T10–T11 and is indicated to manage gastrointestinal dysfunctions of the middle gastrointestinal system (i.e., portions of the pancreas and duodenum, the jejunum, the ileum, the ascending colon, and the proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon), such as IBS. The superior mesenteric ganglion provides sympathetic innervation to the middle gastrointestinal tract via the lesser splanchnic nerve at T10–T11. Contraindications for this technique include aortic aneurysm and a nearby surgical wound.
questions.hint: Abdominal pain, alternating bowel habits, and pain relieved by bowel movements without any red flag symptoms (bloody stool, fever, or weight loss) indicate irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). IBS is associated with changes in sympathetic and parasympathetic tone, although its underlying pathophysiological processes are not fully understood.
